descriptionSet.description: A beautifully ornamented cottage style house with a small tower on the left. Flower boxes can be seen in front of the windows. In the background there is a big mountain visible.

inscription.text: J. Shapoorjee & Co., Allahnbad & Naini Tal.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: J. Shapoorjee & Co., Allahnbad & Naini Tal.
description-en: A beautifully ornamented cottage style house with a small tower on the left. Flower boxes can be seen in front of the windows. In the background there is a big mountain visible. (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: This hospital was renamed the G.B. Pant Hospital after Independence. It was originally built in 1892. (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Architecture was an important visual reminder of "home". The building style most favored in the hill stations has been termed "Himalayan Swiss Gothic." (Shashwati Talukdar)(gs)

related literature: Kenny, Judith 1995. "Climate, Race, and Imperial Authority: The Symbolic Landscape of the British Hill Station in India." In Annals of the Association of American Geographers 85, no. 4 (1995): 694-714. (gs)
related literature: Mathur S. 2007. "India by Design: Colonial History and Cultural Display". Berkeley, Los Angeles, London: University of California Press; pp. 230. (gs)
related literature: Mitchell, W. J. T. 2002 "Imperial Landscape." In Landscape and Power, W. J. T Mitchell, 5-34. Chicago and London: The University of Chicago Press. (gs)

related literature: Pinney, Christpher 1995. “Moral Topophilia: The Significations of Landscape in Indian Oleographs" in The Anthropology of Landscape, ed. Erie Hirsch and Michael O'Hanlon. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

related literature: Talukdar, Shashwati 2010. "Picturing Mountains As Hills. Hill Station Postcards and the Tales They Tell" http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/102/index.html, last accessed 2012-12-17. (gs)
